title: Moto G5 Plus spontaneous "soft reboots" since Daylight Saving Time (DST)?

thread.text: I have a Moto G5 Plus (build #NPNS25.137-93-4), that is up to date with all of the latest patches (Jan 1 2018 security patch) available at this time. The last 2 mornings (since DST change) my phone has spontaneously "soft rebooted" at about 4:15am. It wakes me up when it plays the startup chime and "Hello Moto". I say it's a soft reboot because it is not stopping to ask for my PIN -- thank goodness, otherwise it would be stuck waiting on that input and my alarm wouldn't go off and I'd oversleep! Is anyone else experiencing this? I don't know that it's tied to the DST change, but I haven't updated any Apps recently and it's just odd that it has happened both days at exactly the same time since DST change.

replies.text: Mine did the same thing... Wipe cache and it cleared it right up.

thread.text: Which "cache"? I know how to clear the cache for a specific App, but do you mean something else? According to Google Play I have 196 Apps installed. Do you mean to go in and clear each of those individually, one at a time???

replies.text: You can clear the cache files for all your apps in settings - storage - cached data, but I think @acejavelin means wiping the cache partition from recovery.
Yes, the cache partition... https://motorola-global-portal.custh...p/30,6720,9686
Thank you acejavelin, that seems to have done the trick!

Honestly... That's my go to answer on Moto for weird things that make no sense, seems like about every 3-6 months this needs to be done just to keep things running smoothly. Been that way on all Moto's we have owned since our original Moto G back in 2013, and we have had several.

thread.text: Kind of the same here. I use to wipe the cache partition after any system update.
I thought all Android phones have a wipe cache partition option, not just Moto? I have seen users with other phone models discuss wiping the cache to clear up minor strange issues.

replies.text: Yeah, many devices include this option, but the cache partition has been removed in phones that include the new 'seamless updates/dual partition' feature (Pixels, Z2 Force, X4 ...).
I forgot about that new dual partition feature. Thanks for the reminder.

title: can't change ringtone g5

thread.text: i have a moto g5 and out of the blue it just assigned a ringtone to my incoming calls. i had a custom one selected and when you go into settings it plays all the various ringtones but if you pick one it doesn't take. All calls are answered with a one note bong sound. My custom notification sound works on messages but not the phone. Any suggestions ?

Welcome to Android Central! Is your custom tone file saved to Internal Storage or the SD card? Make sure it's saved to the /Ringtones directory on Internal Storage.
Are you using a ringtones app to save the ringtones, or are you just downloading the files manually and placing them in the /Ringtones directory?

Thanks for all the replies. I understand it will sort of be a lateral move but I'm looking for more ram and more storage (4GB and 64GB) plus SD card support. If my 5X had an SD card I would probably just stay with it. With the G5 Plus only being $299.00 it seems like a good deal.
I do still have concerns about Moto's security patch policy but maybe shouldn't expect too much for $300.00.

I'm quite happy with my G5 plus. It was a bit of a PIA getting it activated with Sprint, but that was on Sprint's side not Moto's fault.
It's an upgrade in every way over the G4 plus with the possible exception of the screen, which is smaller and seems a little less bright than the G4 plus.
The biggest area of improvement is battery life and the processor. I got 5 hours of SOT yesterday which is probably better than any phone I have ever owned including the old Droid Maxx or Droid Turbo. The phone performs flawlessly and I'd bet if you handed it to random people on the street 90% would never guess this isn't a $700 phone.
There are few software differences between the G4 and G5, and most of the few changes are for the better. I particularly like the one button fingerprint controls instead of the on screen buttons. It is a useful and non-obtrusive software modification that feels like it came out of googorola days. It took me about 4 or 5 hours to get used to it and I'm not going back. One software difference I don't like is the new active display widget which doesn't seem necessary, but I can live with it. I guess my love for the active display asthetic going back to the OG Moto X is why I don't like that change.
Overall, this phone is a fantastic value if not an outright fantastic phone in and of itself. Particularly at the Amazon prices.

Thanks for your input. One thing I love about this site is users ability to state in detail why they do or don't like something and all of these posts are very helpful in that regards.
I was leaning towards a Nokia because of the promised updates but it appears that the Nokia's wont work on Verizon so I guess they're out of contention. 
I have a Droid Maxx 2 which I was happy with except for the Verizon bloatware. It had good build quality, great battery life and wasn't too bad performance wise. Once I got used to the fingerprint sensor on the 5X that was it. That is a must have for me now.
I like what Moto does software wise leaving Android more or less alone. The G5 Plus seems to tick all the right boxes for me hardware wise.

One point of advice: if you do pick this phone up, don't go into the Verizon store to activate it. Just take the SIM out of your current active Verizon phone and put it in the G5. It will work. thread.text:
I am not very happy with my Moto G5 Plus. In many ways I preferred my Moto G3. 
My G5 Plus has more software glitches, especially with Google Now and Assistant. 
It doesn't seem significantly faster than my Moto 3 in my typical mundane use.
The camera doesn't seem to process images well in interesting or contrasting light conditions. 
As others noted, the screen is hard to see outside. 
The battery life isn't nearly what I expected. 
Last, but certainly not least, my G5 Plus has significantly poorer Cellular Signal and mobile data signal that any other smartphone I've ever used. I frequent remote locations in my rural area. I count on my phone as an emergency communication device in case someone should be injured. No phone I've had in the last 6 years has been this ineffective in this regard; on the same network, in exactly the same locations. It works well enough that I can't argue it's defective, however. 
Perhaps I've got a lemon here, but I'm quite disappointed with my purchase. Couldn't recommend. 
By contrast, I thought the Moto G3 was a generally wonderful phone, except for the nonexistent security updates.

I wonder if you did get a lemon in this case. Mine has been smoother and with more battery life than any other Android I have had before this (LG G4, Note 4, LG G2, etc). 
Is yours the 2GB or 4GB version?

thread.text:
Very pleasantly surprised: seems snappier overall than the S7 Active I am coming off of.
The 64GB memory is a great improvement over the S7 that was always running out and needed "Active" management.
The camera image quality is worse then the Samsung S7 Active, pretty bad in fact, in low light. But I expected this from the reviews.
The back and recents and home button crunched into the fingerprint censor works GREAT. I don't understand the reviews where it didn't work for the reviewer. I also tried an Axon 7 along the way: the back/recents/home are terrible on that. This is a joy.
I'm not missing NFC: the phone integrates perfectly with my Samsung Gear S3 watch and "Samsung Pay", which is a far better experience than holding a phone over a credit card terminal.
Also in regards to the Axon 7 (a phone which seems crude in comparison, other than its huge bright screen). The Axon could NOT keep a cell signal: it constantly dropped it. So I tried the Moto after seeing reviews, and it was like night and day compared to the Axon 7.
Pleasant surprise? Everyone is hating on the speakers. Well, I am not a golden-ears audio snob, and am more like a cloth-eared nincompoop I guess. I like the speakers for being nicely LOUD, and the Moto G 5th seems as loud as the vaunted Axon 7, and much louder than the Samsung S7 Active.
I'm not needing perfect audio fidelity. I mostly listen to podcasts on the speakers, after all.
Unpleasant surprise? It has no compass. But this is not any sort of deal breaker, and it is "my bad" for not researching this feature first.
Cringeworthy moment? The FLASH graphics boot up cartoon. I suppose if I were 14 years old, I'd love it.

replies.text: I agree on the boot up graphics. At least we can silence the stupid "Hello Moto" sound. 😀

The whole thing, FLASH cartoon, and heavily accented "Hello Moto" is embarassing. always making me wonder if I bought a phone for 14 year olds.
The Axon 7 is similar: the bootup graphics are awful and seem borrowed from an ancient "Sega Genesis".
The iPhone and Samsung bootups are modern and elegant and never embarrassing.

I have the Moto G5 plus and it's the best out there for the price.
PROS:Good battery lifeExcelent fingerprint scannerFast
CONS:Camera is average

I've honestly been blown away by the G5+'s performance. I've actually compared it side by side with a Galaxy S8+ and it was as fast, if not faster in general use and multitasking than the S8+ - and seemed to have better RAM management too.
As everyone said, the camera is the one detractor for the phone. But, at the same time, it's not horrible. I think it's main problem is that it doesn't have optical image stabilization so everything comes out just the slightest bit blurry.
The battery life is phenomenal compared to similar size phones, I don't really have any qualms about the build. It's a little thick, but nothing really noticeable, and the inclusion of a micro-SD slot is a great feature too.
The display...it's not a Samsung display, obviously. Nothing is, really. But I'd say it's as good if not better than the other non-Samsung displays I've used.
If you want pure (or close to pure) android without paying $650-850 bucks for a Pixel, this is really the phone to get.

I have had my G5 Plus for a month. I came from the G4 Plus. The camera is great outdoors but leaves a little to be desired indoors. No NFC in the US is kind of a bummer. Micro USB is old school but works fine. The phone is all around nicer than the 4G Plus. If I know the 5.5 inch S model was coming I would have waited to buy.

The specs all work out to a fabulous deal...
The processor and RAM are competent enough to tackle most tasks yet sip the battery power providing a long life from charge to charge. Near stock Android is a nice plus for me. The size is good for one ha did use, yet not so small that I am wanting for a bigger screen. The camera is ok... Good in well lit environments, poor in bad lighting.
Unfortunately, the build quality is sub par. So you WILL need the warranty. Unfortunately, I have found out first hand that Motorola is derelict of their warranty responsibility. The end result is after 6 months, I have a broken phone and no help from Motorola. Very sad.
Honestly, I wish I could say snap one up, it's a great deal. Unfortunately, if you want a phone that'll work 12 months from now, you need to keep looking. 
My 2 cents.

Got the 2/32 Gb version of the Moto G5 plus for my teenage daughter last fall. It's been a fantastic phone for her. She uses the HECK out of it - all kinds of apps running at the same time! And I never hear any complaints about the battery life. It's not the phone for me due to the screen size, camera specs, and no NFC, but the G5+ remains a darn good - and a perfect device for her.

Once Moto tests it internally, they select a group of Moto Feedback Network users to test it, and that runs for 30-60 days before general release, assuming there are no issues discovered while testing. If there are issues in the beta/soak test, it returns to development, it's fixed, and the process starts over. Nougat for the Moto X Pure took almost 8 months.

title: Motorola G5 Plus - Google isn't responding error

thread.text: My wife is getting "Google isn't responding" error messages on her new G5 Plus. Has anyone else had this problem? Found a work-around?

Hmm... Never seen this, maybe because I did the "trick" to get Google Assistant to work shortly after I got my G5+.
Go to Settings - Apps and scroll down to Google (just the app named "Google") and tap on it, then tap Storage and Clear Data, then reboot. If in Settings-Apps-Google your device says "Manage Space" instead of Clear Data, tap that and there should be an option to Clear All Data, select it and confirm, then reboot the device. Google Assistant should show up shortly by long pressing the Home button to activate, it should be Google Assistant now and not Google Screen Search anymore.
Since I did this, I have had ZERO issues with Google search.

I had this problem sincerely day 1 when I bought it within 2 weeks of it being in stock at Best Buy. It resolved itself when the March update came rolling through. Previously I had done multiple resets and factory resets which including installing from cloud or app but app. Nothing worked until the March update.
The problem was solved with the latest update  to the phone. I hope others have seen this improvement as well.

Gotta say yes... It's creation date is the same as other folders like Ringtones and Podcasts, which are created for the user by the system. 
It's been seen in Moto devices for several years now, since about G 2015 and X Pure/Style, and if you remove it, it just comes back next boot.
It's not malware or a virus, nor is it from a failed rooting attempt as Google may try to tell you... We don't know what it's for exactly, possibly something used in updates but we don't know for sure.

title: Does the G5+ have a notification LED?

thread.text: I've just upgraded from a 2014 Moto G to a G5 Plus. On the G there was a tiny white LED that slowly pulsated to alert you of notifications. I don't see this on the G5+. Is there one, or is there a setting to activate it?
There is a hidden LED which blinks when I power on my phone but it doesn't provide an alert for notifications. I don't think you can activate it without root access.

Moto G5 Plus has a hidden LED indicator, which is located at the earpiece speaker. But Motorola has disabled its function as a notification indicator. This LED works when the time of battery completely dead as well as the time of charging. If you are ready to root the phone, then you can use the LED as a notification indicator, but it is risky, because you may lose your warranty on the phone.

Be aware that even if you root the device, this LED only functions when when you are connected to external power (USB or adapter) because it is hard wired into the charging circuit. Honestly, this LED is useless.

Fix for MOTO G5 Plus Phone Volume - Simple Setting Change
Click Green Phone Icon to get to the main Phone menu.
Open Settings (3 vertical dots upper right corner)
Select Settings then select Calls then Uncheck the Voice Privacy box [ ]
This will fix your telephone volume problem by deactivating the DEFAULT Volume Privacy buffer
If you would like a tad more volume: 
From the Call setting menu Go back one page to the Settings menu
Select Accessibility and checkmark the Turn on hearing aid compatibility box [x] 
If you are having problems keeping any volume control level from falling from 100% back to 75%, 
simply hold the volume dot at 100% and simultaneously select [OK] in the excessive volume message.
Hope this helps. Bob

title: Software Modified in moto g5 plus xt1686 indian variant

thread.text:
I have modified device and facing too many problems. I want to make it official. so, what can i do ?
Please anyone help me ?

replies.text:
This depends entirely on your version currently installed... In order to return to an official state, three things must occur. 
1) You must flash an official image that is the same or newer version than what you have installed
2) You must (re)lock the bootloader, which requires #1 to occur
3) You must accept an OTA update and allow to apply properly (only way to change status "Modified" to "Official" after relocking the bootloader)
Be aware that Moto does NOT release or support any factory firmware images, the only ones we have have been leaked out and we do not have the latest versions for any variant, and some variants have newer version (1 or 2 versions old) and some are much older (Marshmallow versions). This means #1 is difficult to do. Item #2 is simple, if you can accomplish #1 . 
At this point, you would be back to as pure stock as is possible, although the software status would show "Modified" or unofficial, there should be no errors or issues with software or other services. Getting the status of "Official" does require accepting an OTA from this state.
Remember that you can NEVER completely hide the fact the device has been modified. Your bootloader status can never be set back to 0 (LOCKED), but only to 2 (RE-LOCKED). Warranty can never be reinstated, once the unlock code has been issued by Moto, regardless of whether it is used or not, the warranty is void. Even if the bootloader has been relocked, the Bootloader Unlocked warning screen will still be displayed on every startup (this can be masked with a custom logo.img, but any subsequent update with clear it again). 
The real question here should be what problems are you having, what have you done, and can these issue be corrected? Lots of users unlock and modify their G5+ devices successfully, so there is likely assistance out there. I would recommend visiting XDA's Moto G5 Plus forum for more information on modified devices and correcting issues.

title: Moto G5 Plus: do I need the 64GB version?

thread.text:
I just bought a 32GB Moto G5 Plus, which I'm using for a couple of weeks before passing it on to my wife. She doesn't ask much from her phone, so I knew the 32GB version would be fine for her. I was planning to buy myself a 64GB G5 once I was sure I liked the phone (mainly for the 4GB of RAM).
But the more I use this 32GB model, the more I ask myself if I really need the one with more storage. Performance is great; I have a micro-SD card, so I'm really not worried about running out of space. Will the extra 2GB of RAM make a difference in performance, or in apps getting dumped out of memory? Has anybody tried both versions, and if so, is there any noticeable difference?
I'm all about being a cheapskate, so if I can avoid paying an extra $50 for features I don't need, so much the better...

It all depends on your personal usage. My wife is quite happy with her 2/32 G5 plus, but I went to the G5S+ mostly for the extra RAM (here the G5+ 4/64 model is not available). This is what I think.
Storage. Having an SD is good, but quite limited for some things. If you only want to use it for your media files it's fine, pushing it a little bit for more complicated stuff, like Spotify playlists for example, is going to give some headaches. The more internal storage the better.
Memory. You are going to notice the extra RAM mostly when multitasking or running heavy apps. It does makes a difference for me. Really important? Not really, but the difference is there.
Personally, I would go for the 4/64 model and forget about the $50

replies.text:
Yeah, you're probably right. Best Buy is going to have the 64GB version in their Black Friday sale, and it's not like this is an expensive phone even at full price!

I'm not saying don't get the 4/64... That's actually what I am using. Just know Murphy's Law and Motorola will do everything possible to keep it from living beyond (or even up to) 2 years. Lol.

title: How run selfi stick in Moto g5

thread.text: How run selfi stick in Moto g5

Welcome to Android Central! Is it a Bluetooth stick or one that plugs into the headphone jack? The way most sticks work, you have to go to the Camera app's settings and change the Volume button function to Shutter Release (instead of Zoom or Volume). title: best cheap ear phones or buds

replies.text: The real question is what is "cheap" to you? To some people that's $10, to others $50 or $100 is "cheap" for headphones.

thread.text: Wired or Bluetooth? I have LG Tone Pro HBS-750 Bluetooth headphones, which are quite good. You can find the HBS-770 at Techrabbit.com for $25 refurbished: LG HBS-770 Tone Pro Wireless Bluetooth Stereo Headset | Tech Rabbit

Honesly, for ear buds in this price range, anything from Sennheiser... like the CX300 (replaced by CX 3.00 I guess), Klipsch Image S4A (although the new R6 series that replaced them are reviewing really bad, you can till find the S4 series online), or a surprisingly good budget earbud is SoundMagic E series (E10, E50, or E80) but avoid ES series like ES18. 
Running cheaper, Symphonized NRG 3.0 Earbuds are about $25USD and are honestly very good for the money... If you are really into audio, spring the extra bucks and look at 1MORE Triple Driver In-Ear headphones but you are now getting close to $100.

Good luck!
(If your wondering, I am using iBeats by Monster... they came with my old HTC in 2011 but are still in great shape, tried lots of headphones but keep going back to these, not so much by choice though, my kids keep stealing mine)

title: app shortcuts disappear

thread.text: So whenever, I put app shortcuts on my home screen. I've noticed they slowly disappear from the home screen. I still have the apps installed. Just it seems as if my home screens self clean? Any ideas?
Are you using Adopted Storage for your SD card, if so that cause issues like this if the card is starting to fail.
yes I'm using the SD card as Internal memory. so the SD card is failing?

replies.text:
I didn't say that... but it is a possibility. One of the symptoms of a failing sd card used as adopted storage is apps disappear from the desktop. Basically the phone loses touch with the sd card momentarily and then reconnects to it, the app is still there, but the icon disappears from the desktop.
Honestly, I would NEVER use an sd card as adopted storage, only portable... the moderators (Moto employees) on the Lenovo support forums say the same thing. If you had an old Moto G with 8GB of storage it might be worth it, but in a device with 32 or 64 it is purely a waste and puts unnecessary stress on the sd card and increases the possibility of lost data like photos and videos.

I couldn't agree more with @acejavelin. Adoptable storage is the last resort for a 8gb phone. A failing card will mess your phone for good and it'll be very difficult to get things back to normal if this happen. Too risky for my liking.
Try to revert to external storage from settings - storage - SD card and leave the card just for media files and such.

thread.text: Thank you both. I will do that. I have 64gb internal. just thought of expanding it. if that's the case, it's not worth the risk.

replies.text:
Unless you have hundreds and hundreds of apps and games installed, you will never use up 64GB of storage... I have 190 apps installed and am using only 5GB of space, for pictures I set the camera to save to sd card, otherwise everything uses internal storage. 
Honestly, after you have migrated back to portable storage, if possible I would throw that card (or move it to unimportant uses) and get a new one... Adopted storage really is that hard on an SD card.

title: how is the G5+ camera?

thread.text: I think title speaks for itself, but I am looking into getting a new phone soon. My two biggest things I'm looking for is a decent camera. And good battery life. I know the 625 is a battery life beast. So my only real question here is. How is the camera?

I have not been particularly impressed overall with the G5 plus camera. Sure - it takes fine casual shots in decent lighting but suffers from good shots in low light. I do not think it has optical image stabilization either. I think the key is what you mean by "decent" - it has been fine for my basic usage - candid snapshots, basic nature scenes, etc. But have not had the best results with say, close up macro shots and super clear words or details, etc. 
In my opinion anyone looking for the camera as a *standout* feature on a phone should probably look at something else.

thread.text: I agree with the last post. it's good but not stand out good. again close up shots are good as are quick point and shoot. but for those long lingering sunsets it's a photo shop and filters galore for a decent pic. The bundled filters and tools are just about average but nothing to write home about. Apart from that the g5 plus is a great phone at its price point.

thread.text:
Well the kids went back to school yesterday here in the UK. Took loads of pics as there is new uniforms. The pics were fine for that. Maybe a little too bright but that's because I'd turned up the brightness by accident. 
it's ok for those quick snaps IMHO. If I want lingering sunsets, I break out a proper camera.

I agree - I think it would be pretty decent for pictures like this, unless you are specifically wanting to take pictures in low light (e.g., baby sleeping, etc.).
I have not fully played around with the camera app, but it does have some nifty features such as automatically taking more than 1 picture so you can choose the best one. I also like that if you rotate 90 deg left for landscape (seems most people put into landscape this way), puts the volume rocker at the top, and the volume up can be used as the camera shutter button. Totally mental thing, but this does make it feel a bit more like a camera  If you press & hold the volume for a bit, it will take multiple pictures rapidly so you can choose the best one & delete the rest, etc.
And of course the Moto gesture of double wrist twist to quickly open the camera (even when locked) can be helpful for quick photos.
thank you both for the long responses it seems that the camera will suit what I need it to do. I think I may just buy it and give it a try.

I've been very happy with mine. Other than the mediocre camera, only other gripe is that the body is a bit large for a 5.2" screen phone (e.g. - my prior LG G4 was about the same physical size but had a 5.5" screen). 
But a ton of good things - as you already said, battery life is incredible. Also is very fluid & smooth - not bogged down with loads of unnecessary apps like you typically get with carrier branded phones. Fingerprint sensor is fast and conveniently on the front, home button gestures lets you remove the on-screen nav buttons giving you that much more screen space, gestures for camera and flashlight are super useful, etc.
I am not crazy about the default launcher especially with the non-removable Google search bar and page but installing a 3rd party launcher like Nova takes care of that
how are the button gestures by the way, pretty accurate?

Pretty accurate for me. Still not 100% like a true button press - if I am sloppy when sliding left for back button, it sometimes ends up as a home button press. Just have to be a *bit* careful but does not require exaggerated or overly deliberate sliding gestures.

The "tap for home" is a real annoyance actually, especially in apps that use the fingerprint scanner to log you in, it just returns you to the home screen about 1/2 the time.
As far as the camera goes, I'm spoiled and came from a Moto X Pure, which had amazing camera front and back... In the MG5+ the selfie camera sucks in comparison (I don't actually use it for selfies, but often to read serial numbers or mac addresses from the back of equipment in a data rack) but the main camera is decent, nothing amazing but nothing terrible, but I knew this going in and the battery life trade-off was well worth it to me. title: Unable to transfer photos to pc

thread.text: My pc is windows 10 and I've updated my drivers with media package, my phone is Moto G5 and is set to MTP to import photos but for some reason I get an error message saying it can't import, I've had Motoirola on it who want to reset or repair the phone which is 2 months old & doesn't need it, I'm just missing something thats all. HELP PLEASE.

replies.text:
Guess I am a little confused... there are no drivers required for MTP mode, Windows 7 and newer all come with MTP drives embedded into the OS, and it just shows up as a device in My Computer. From there you can just open it and navigate to the appropriate directory and copy like normal.
When issues arise, it is usually from only a couple things... 
The media database in the phone is out of sync with the actual files (MTP doesn't let you access the directories directly even though it appears that way, you are accessing a database) and those can be corrected by first disconnecting the USB cable, then going to Settings - Apps and tap the 3 button overflow menu and select "Show System", then scroll down and find External Storage and Media Storage. Open each of those and tap Storage, then Clear Data (you will not lose any data, only the databases are deleted), and then reboot. After the phone appears to be up and operating normally let it sit for at least 5 minutes for the databases to rebuild automatically (there is no notification this is occurring or completed) and then reconnect the USB and try to access your files.
The other issue is with your computer... there are some issues with USB drivers, there can be OS corruption of the configuration, and hardware defects. First try a different USB port, preferably one of a different "type", meaning if you had it connected to a USB 3.0 port, try a USB 2.0 port, or vis-versa. If this fails, I would recommend downloading a Linux image and make a live bootable USB flash drive and boot to that, then connect the phone and see if you can access it (Linux requires no drivers to talk to an Android device), if you can you have a Windows or driver problem, if it doesn't work you likely have an odd hardware compatibility.
One last thing would be trying to connect the phone either after a booting in Safe Mode, or after a factory reset.
Of course, all of this can be eliminated if you just use Google Photos to automatically backup all your photos online... you don't need to physically connect your device to your computer at all, just go to https://photos.google.com to access all your pictures at anytime.

There should be no need for any special "import" program.
After you connect the phone to the computer, unlock the security screen, and accept the computer connection, can you browse the phone like a hard drive using Windows File Explorer? If yes, just use File Explorer to drag and drop your files from the phone to the computer.

thread.text: Yes, Google photos will do it all without thinking about it!

Cheers Guys, I downloaded the Media Package because that's what Motorola told me to do, saying my drivers needed updating. My pc is an old 1 so I think I only have a 2 port, as you can tell I'm a Homer Simpson type tech head,DOH, so not up with all the wordings etc or anything come to that, it's an age thing. I have Google Photos but it makes no difference, I still get the error message but I will try Acejavelins 1st suggestion, so I may be back but if not thank you again.

replies.text:
If you like, I would like to try to get your problem resolved!
Go to Google Photos on your phone. Go to settings, back up & sync, and make sure it is marked. Be sure to be on Wi-Fi, if you have a lot of photos, and limited data. Next, go to https://photos.google.com/ on your computer. You don't need anything connecting the phone and the computer. It will sync via the internet. Sign into Google Photos on your computer with your Google account, and the photos should be there. Please let me know.

title: Adoptable microSD disappeared (Nougat, Moto G5 plus) - how to access it?

thread.text:
Hi,
I have a Motorola/Lenovo Moto G5 Plus with Android Nougat. I have a Sandisk Ultra 128gb formatted as adoptable/internal storage. So it is linked to that phone.
While listening to a song it stopped working, just disappeared. It is not visible in the settings-storage. After a reboot the internal storage space went down to 24gb (phone memory). The problem is I can't see the SD card as a device anywhere (phone Total commander, SD card adapter&card reader on Mac, windows, linux), so I can't format it again. SanDisk claims the micro SD card is fine. 
I don't care about the files, but shouldn't it pop up as a device it was still working?
Any ideas on how to see the card again? Or is it just completely gone (wouldn't be the first Sandisk SD card to fail after a few months)? 
Thanks for any idea!

Adoptable storage adopts the SD card as part of internal storage, so you can't "access the SD card", you can only access "internal SD" storage - which includes the space on the SD card.
If you want the card to act the way it used to, format it as Portable Storage, and you'll have internal SD and external SD. (The whole idea of adoptable storage is to "expand" the internal storage of the device.)

Thanks, yes that's what I wanted it for, but it just stopped being there for no reason. So my phone has 32gb internal built-in memory + 128gb from the card (minus the system) and that was my internal memory. I can't see the card anymore and after the restart the internal memory dropped to 24 gb. If I put it a normal portable micro SD from another phone that works as expected.
The question is: Is the card defect or did my phone just "forget" it was supposed to have an internal SD card?

It's possible that the card is counterfeit. (The "card" is actually a whole computer - storage for you, a CPU and storage for the CPU. A 4k card can be reprogrammed to say that it's 128K, but as soon as you put more than 4k on it, you overwrite the beginning of its storage, and all sorts of bad things - like the card disappearing - can happen. If the phone won't read the card, format it in your PC as a normal exFAT card, put it into the phone and run SD Insight. If it doesn't show that it's a smaller card right away, look at the manufacture date. If it's 1 Jan 1970, it's counterfeit. (In Unix date-time, that's 0, and many counterfeiters just zero all of storage and don't put a legitimate-looking date in.)
If it's not a counterfeit card, contact SanDisk microSD Tech Support (live chat at the upper right) and ask for help. They're pretty good. (Their cards are a bit more expensive than others, but I don't buy any other brand - I like good tech support.)

title: Why does the Volume on my MotoG5 decrease when the front sensor is covered

thread.text: On my Moto G5 when the front proximity sensor is covered the Notification sound volume is decreased by approximately 95%.This happens when the phone is in my pocket so I can't hear it.I have proved this by calling my phone from my landline and covering the sensor.If the sensor is NOT covered then the sound is at full volume,this only occurs when the sensor is covered even when the flip case is closed.This happens on all notifications eg- Calls,E-Mail,TXT Msg's etc.Can anyone help or advise me what I can do to sort this out as I'm not at all technically minded when it comes to phones???Many Thanks.
Welcome to Android Central! Open your Moto app, select Actions, and make sure Flip For Do Not Disturb is off.

Thanks for your reply and I have checked that and it's OFF but I still have this problem if I have the flip case open then the volume is at full but if I close the case or put the phone in my pocket the volume decreases by about 95% and I have a job to hear the phone, thank God that the phone also vibrates so I can tell when I receive any​ new notifications. I just don't know what to try next????Any suggestions on this problem gratefully received.
Does this happen in Safe Mode? https://motorola-global-en-uk.custhe...eset/safe-mode

I have tried this in the SAFE MODE and it's still the same,the sound is cut by about 95% when the phone front is covered but if left uncovered the volume is at full and OK.I have also found out that when in SAFE MODE the E-Mail notification does not sound, all I get is an icon to alert me that I have received an E-Mail???

Can you clarify -- did you mean that covering the proximity sensor only while keeping the flip cover open also makes the sound really low? You mentioned in your OP that covering the sensor while the flip cover was closed made the sound low. I'm just trying to determine if the sound is low only because the flip cover is closed, since the phone's main speaker is on the front of the phone (not the back), and could therefore be muffled by the flip cover.

Hi there if the flip cover is open and I cover the sensor with my fingertip the sound is cut by approx 95% and when in SAFE MODE there is no notification sound at all when the sensor is covered either with my fingertip or by closing the flip case.When the sensor is NOT covered either by my fingertip or the case the volume is at full and OK.I have done a factory reset on the phone as instructed by Motorola Tech Dept but it's still the same so I don't know what to try next as when the phone is in my pocket I can't hear it at all even if I take it out of the case????Regards,Trevor.
Sorry, I'm stumped. I'm not sure why it would happen with the Flip for Do Not Disturb setting off, and why it would happen in Safe Mode and after a reset. What happens if you take the flip cover off?

If the case is removed it's exactly the same as I said in my last reply I said that if I take it out of the case the problem still occurs so it looks like I'm going to have to get my money back and steer clear of Motorola products as I've only had this phone 4 weeks???Regards,Trevor.

Hi there just to let you know I covered the sensor with my finger outside my house and the sound is cut.I removed my finger and the sound is back to full.So on the flip case which has a cut out for the front speaker/earpiece I punched a hole into the leather with a leather punch to give a clearance hole around the proximity sensor.On closing the flip case with the sensor NOT COVERED by the case as I can see it through the punched hole the sound level is STILL CUT?????I cannot work this out as it now appears that if the phone front is covered the volume on all Notifications is cut by approx 95% so it can't be heard as I had 2 E-Mails with the phone in my pocket and never heard them???Regards Trevor.
I wish I had an answer for you, but this is difficult to explain. If I were you, I'd probably be banging my head against the wall as well!

Such a weird problem! I agree with B. Diddy, this sounds like there's something wrong with the Flip for Do not Disturb feature or maybe any other Moto Action that relies on the proximity sensor. Or maybe something deeper in the system.
Since the factory reset didn't fix the problem it could mean that you have a defective unit (sadly, it happens) or that there's some conflict in your settings that was restored after the reset.
Just in case you could try a couple of things.
- Reset app preferences.
- Force stop and clear data for the Moto/Moto Actions apps.
- Clear data for the settings app to restore the original options.
Remember to restart the phone after this.
By the way, did this problem start all of a sudden or has it been the same from day one?

Good Morning and many thanks for your reply and help,I will follow your latest suggestions and try to reset the preferences for apps and clear all data and force stop for the Moto/Moto Actions apps then I will clear all data for the settings app.Then I will turn the phone off and then re power the phone to see what happens??This problem started about 4 days after I had the phone and I first noticed it as I felt the phone Vibrate in my pocket so I thought I had turned the Vol off BUT I hadn't then I found out all the symptoms I have described to you.I have been offered a replacement phone if this problem cannot be fixed and if I can't get it sorted out with your excellent help then I shall take up the offer of a replacement phone.I will run the phone for 24 hours after I have done all your suggestions then get back to you to let you know how it's performing.Best Wishes and many thanks,Trevor.

Good Morning,I received a new replacement phone swapped over my 2 SIM cards and my 64 GB Sd Card and installed the Apps that I described in my last update to you and I still have the same problem???If the display of the new phone is covered the volume on all notifications is cut by approx 95% but if left uncovered so that the WHOLE DISPLAY is open to view thee volume is at full and is OK so I'm at a complete loss as what to try next??????Any suggestions????I await your reply,Yours Trevor.

Good Afternoon to you all,Just an update on my sound problem with my MotoG5.This afternoon I have received my phone back from the Motorola Repair Center here in the UK.With the phone is a letter stating that "A detailed examination has been carried out by Motorola Qualified Engineers and are pleased to advise that the fault that you have reported has been identified and a full repair has been carried out.Also we have installed the latest Manufacturer's software to your device.Regards The Lenovo Repairs Team" This is what is contained in the letter.On re-installing my SIM's and SD card the phone seems to perform as it should,when covered the sound is now at full both in my pocket and in the flip case.I will give it a few days and keep you all informed.Best Wishes,Trevor.

title: Moto g5 Plus with Samsung s7...

thread.text:
Hi y'all. I just bought a G5 Plus because my s7 Edge crapped out on me. I love the phone and all, but it's lacking in something's that I miss of the s7.
So here's my question, is there a way I can get the screenshot capability and the gallery app that my Samsung had onto my Moto?
I've tried looking for apps to suffice in the Google Play store but no avail. Help?

Welcome to Android Central! Moved from the Android Apps forum to the Moto G5 Plus forum, since the former is intended for developers to promote their apps.
All Android phones can take screenshots. Press and hold Power and Vol Down together for about half a second. You have to make sure you press them exactly at the same time -- it can take a bit of practice to get used to it.
Unless Samsung made their proprietary apps available to other devices, you can't use them on a non-Samsung phone. What features in the Samsung Gallery app do you miss? There are probably some 3rd party gallery apps that can meet those needs.

I know how to take screenshots
However, I prefer the way it was on the s7 because it allowed me to crop as well as draw before I saved the screenshot.
That's why I was wondering if I could somehow her the way the s7 screenshotted into the g5.
With the gallery, I just liked how it was set up on the Samsung. Ok the Moto there was only Google Photos which had limited ability on editing photos within the gallery.

replies.text: The function you are asking for was a function of the Samsung gallery app. You can crop resize and add filters to photos directly from the Google photos app by selecting the picture and hitting the pencil looking icon to edit.

thread.text:
Oh ok -- you had only asked about screenshot capability in your first post. Try Screenshot Crop & Share.
It's probably not tightly integrated with Google Photos, but try Snapseed.

title: Moto G5 plus batttery jumps to 0% and shuts off

thread.text: My moto G5 plus started shutting off randomly today and when I looked into it a little further it turns out the battery suddenly drained from ~70% down to nothing. I rebooted and then the phone went in to shut down mode immediately and turned off again. I charged the phone for an hour on the turbo charger and it charged up to 53% and stayed at that amount so I unplugged it. 20 minutes later the phone jumped to 0 powered off then when I rebooted it had 98% battery. What is going on here.
It could be false reporting by a bad battery. Does it persist in Safe Mode?

replies.text: 'm in safe mode now and the battery is draining very fast went from 75% to 40% inside of 10 minutes and battery info in android says screen 1% so it doesn't make sense

thread.text: Okay. In the battery usage graph, are there any sudden vertical drops, or are they just steep downward inclines?

I tried to post a screenshot in my original post but they were sudden vertical drops. Then I would power on again it would say I have plenty of battery left then after 10-15 min another sudden vertical drop. I did a factory reset of the phone and now it is more of a gradual dowward decline but from a full charge it reports only able to run for 2 hours which is absolutely terrible for this phone as it used to last for 10+ hours

I'm thinking it's most likely to be a bad battery. The nearest thing from my own experience was with a Lumia 1020, which would indicate heavy battery drain for no apparent reason. Even if fully charged, it might suddenly show low battery, then full battery after rebooting. In that case I fixed it by uninstalling a couple of apps that I thought might be giving trouble, which is why I mentioned Safe Mode earlier.
I'll move the thread to the Moto G5 Plus forum for comments from other users.
Also, welcome as a new member.

I booted into bootloader and went to the factory section and it says "battery ok" in green. Another thing I noticed is that from 100% to dead then reboot is roughly half an hour. When it reboots it has roughly 9% less than the previous time the phone thought it was dead. Just a pattern I noticed

title: Moving from Pixel to G5 Plus

thread.text:
Hi,
I have been using the Pixel since it came out, mainly because I saw Assistant as very promising (and wanted to try Daydream). I came to the realization that, despite a decade of using flagships, that a midrange phone would likely meet my use case.
Short summery: love this phone. Functionally, it seems as zippy as my Pixel, and there's almost nothing I can't do on this phone that the Pixel could. (and I really loved the little Moto additions on my Moto X years ago, and they are just as fun on this).
Just thought I'd throw out my 2 cents, in case there are some who have flagship envy.

replies.text: Moto g5 plus is a nice device. Outside of maybe the camera, you won't really notice a difference between the "mid range" devices and flagships anymore. (unless you're big into gaming)

For a third of the price! The g5 plus easily stacks up to the Pixel.

title: g5 plus WiFi issue

thread.text: Has anyone here been afflicted with the G5 WiFi issue mentioned on many places? I bought a g5p to replace my daughters g3 and on the home Wi-Fi it works great, on the campus wide Wi-Fi in college it disconnects often... Supposedly it has to do with secured networks.

Yes, I'm having problems with my new G5 plus. It takes forever to connect on my homework while it works great at my office and usually on public networks when I'm out and about.
The home network works fine with my wife's iPhone and our laptops but on the G5, I often get the message "authentication problem" or "poor signal," even if I'm in the same room as the wireless router.
The security is reported as WPA2 PSK on the G5, but I don't know what that means.
I pressed the WPS button, which I believe is a security protocol, on my router/modem and now everything is working great with the Moto G5 plus wireless Go figure.
This works great if you're the owner of the router. Unfortunately in college or work environments that's not always the case. I'll try to switch to the college guest network and see if it helps!

title: Ex iPhone user wondering about the lack of security patches: how big a deal is that?

thread.text:
I got the Moto G5 Plus at Costco for $219. The 32 meg version.
I love the phone and like it a lot better than my iPhone 6s due screen size, battery life, Google integration, ease of use, and 1/3 the price for an unlocked phone.
My only concern is the lack of operating system updates and security patches that I gather can be a problem with Android phones in general and the Moto phones in particular.
How big a "real world" problem is this? One thing Apple does well, IMHO, is keep all their phones --including models several years old -- updated.
Do Android users just have to buy a phone every year or two to get the latest operating system or critical updates? If so, the apparent savings of my Moto G5 Plus is more imagined than real: buying a new version every year basically equates to buying an iPhone 6s--which I have--and keeping it three years.
I have 90 days to return the Moto G5 Plus and need help assessing how big a problem the lack of timely updates is for the average user (vs. a power user, which I am not).
Thanks, 
Bob

I think this is still a major issues for OEMs. One way to possibly counteract this is to flash a custom ROM that is well supported and updates after the base AOSP code is (Think Lineage, formerly Cyanogen). I think I would, at worst, be comfortable with a device that updated every other month for security patches. If a device company can keep that up, they would be doing quite well in my opinion.

Thanks for the feedback.
I'd certainly be comfortable with a phone that updated every couple of months but it is my understanding the Moto G5 Plus hasn't updated since January (perhaps at the time of release).
As to the rest of your counsel, I'm afraid that's way above my paygrade given my newbie status, but thanks for trying.

There was just a new release for the May security updates. We still don't know how frequent they will be.
IMHO it's not that big of a deal if you limit yourself to apps from the Play Store and don't leave the setting to download other apps open.

replies.text: Also mine hasn't updated and I check once a week any idea why?

For some (including myself) you can get the update by powering the phone off. Pulling the sim card. Powering the phone back on without the sim card. Then the OTA update to NPNS25.137-35-5 (May 1, 2017) appeared and could be installed.
Based on my past exerience with Motorola (i've owned several of their phones over the years) they are slow on pushing updates to their phones. I just hope they don't abandon the G5 Plus as its a good phone with good features and with a few tweaks and fixes could be even better.
So far the phone has been very good for me. The only issue I've had so far is with an older Motorola H500 bluetooth headset not working properly with the phone yet the phone bluetooth function works appears to work with my Garmin Nuvi hands free feature. Other then that the phone (knock on wood) has worked great. Battery life is good (so far).

thread.text: Other than the updates how are you enjoying the phone?
No--I just checked a week or two ago and the update was there. Maybe they roll them out like the carriers do????
I still haven't seen it yet.
That's still way behind schedule. May patch in July? I suppose for Motorola it's better than nothing.
Thx for this suggestion. I'll give it a try.
Mine updated last night. I just did the usual check through settings.

replies.text: May 1st security updates and still stuck on Android 7.0

thread.text: Yeah that's what mine is at too.

title: Future updates

thread.text: So is there any word what type of future updates the g5 plus will get? I know moto isn't the best with updates but doesn't even seem to be getting security patches..

Motorola is apparently trying to be the absolute worst OEM when it comes to security patches. With Moto's minimal changes to stock Android you would think rolling in a patch every half year or so wouldn't be too difficult.

replies.text: Agree. Crazy they are so bad, even with security patches.

thread.text: Heard it was quarterly. Probably can expect one or maybe two major OS updates. I'm not sure of Motonovo's track record with updating their G-series.
Quarterly I could live with. My G5 Plus is still on January.

replies.text: Do you really need quarterly updates. I mean I don't download sketchy apps, sideload anything or visit websites that are compromising. Even if I did do the Security patches make that much of a difference? I'm just trying to understand the whole thing.

Let's put it this way. Google thinks it important enough to issue monthly updates to Nexus and Pixel devices. I myself do not frequent the sort of sites that may cause problems but the patches may also address other exploits and what's wrong with being as safe as possible?
In Moto's case it seems especially frustrating because their version of Android is so close to stock that one would think it shouldn't be all that difficult.
I bought a G5 knowing Moto's previous history hoping for some improvement so that's on me.
I guess my thought process is still fairly rooted in iOS and the random updates that are not scheduled. I see your point.

Staying away from sketchy apps and dodgy websites is a good practice on any device that is on the internet in my opinion. But having an OS that is up to date security wise just adds another layer of protection. Absolutely necessary? Maybe not. Desirable? Yes as far as I'm concerned.

With the constant hacking going on, yes, security updates are almost more important than OS updates. I don't download sketchy apps either, but look at the constant hacks (Verizon is latest) that is not user error (a vzw employee caused it) I still want my phone to be secure because you can never be too safe anymore

thread.text: The last time I checked Moto has more phones on Nougat than any other manufacturer, and the first manufacturer to update phones to Nougat after the Pixel received it. They may not publish monthly security updates every single month, but they have been good about OS updates.
Well my Maxx 2 never received the Nougat update that was promised but Verizon is involved in that so who knows. About the only time you will get a security patch from Moto is IF you get an OS update.
If you like to root. This phone has amazing ROM support, so its easy to always have the lasted build through custom roms.

replies.text:
Being able to root and having ROM support is great for those that want to tinker a lot. I buy unlocked phones so I don't have to root to purge all the bloatware from my phone. I would really rather not have to deal with all that just to have an up to date device.
OEMs really need to step up and provide timely security updates. Overall I am personally less concerned with OS versions than I am with security patches.

title: Moto G5 screen won't turn on after night

thread.text:
Hi. I just bought a Moto G5 a couple of days ago.
Everything was fine at the beginning. Even the first night with it was perfectly fine.
After the second night, I tried to unlock it with my fingerprint and it worked... but the screen didn't respond. The phone vibrates to let me know it unlocked but I fail to get image.
I tried again and again but no luck. I had to reset the phone to make it work.
Anyone else having this issue?

Welcome to Android Central! Moved from the Nougat forum to the Moto G5 forum.
It could be some app you installed that's causing the instability. If it keeps happening, try booting into Safe Mode to see if it happens then. https://motorola-mobility-en-in.cust...eset/safe-mode
The only thing I did was install Slack and disable the Google app. I'm curious if that's what's causing the issue.

replies.text: Welcome to the forums. Did the Google app remain disabled after you restarted the phone? I wonder if the Moto G5 stock launcher (Launcher3) relies on some components included in the Google app.
Turns out the cold weather is causing the screen to dim a lot or completely shut down. Can this be fixed or should I change the phone?

How cold, way below 0°C? Phones are designed to work in cold weather, but there are some limits where they will start to fail.
Also, are you leaving the phone at night on a cold surface (metal, glass, ceramic ...)?

thread.text: I'm running Nova, but it didn't complain the first night.
I'm leaving it on a desk next to an open window. It does get cold (the phone). But I don't know the exact temp. Maybe tomorrow at the coldest point of the night I'll check and let you know.

title: Moto G5 plus Turbo Power charger - nor very "turbocharged"

thread.text:
I bought a brand new Moto G5 Plus last week and its Turbo Power charger doesn't charge very quick...I have a charger from my Nexus 5 phone that charges the G5+ faster. 
The Moto G5+ TurboPower charger has 3A output and the LG Nexus 5 charger has a 1.8A output...
What's the deal here???

Is it maybe the cable you're using? Some smaller gauge cables may not offer the same voltage.
When you plug it in, does the phone give you a message that it is "Turbopower Connected" at the bottom of the lockscreen?
BTW, this is just Quickcharge 2.0 technology, so if you have one of those chargers (or above), try it instead.

I'm using the original Motorola charger that came with the phone. It does say "Turbopower connected" and until it reaches 100% sometimes it estimates 1 hour from 50% or less...maybe the phone needs to adapt to it?

title: How do I get the disappearing keyboard back?

thread.text:
I'm a former iPhone user, happily making the transition to Android since I live in a Windows/Google-centric universe.
One maddening problem I'm having, however, on my Moto G plus (Android 7.0) is that when I dictate a text or email, and want to use the keyboard to clean up a mistake or two, I can't find it. The little-colored cursor icon appears and I tap it, but it just gives me more text options, not a keyboard.
Where does the keyboard go in these instances and how do I find it when I need it?
In settings, my Physical keyboard is set to "Speech." What setting, widget, or whatever do I need to access in order to fix this problem?
Tried to search the forum for help on this but didn't turn up anything.
Thx for any help offered.
Bob

Welcome to the forums. You should have a physical keyboard also in Settings to choose from, though I have not used the speech function. I have moved your post to the Moto G forum for more help from fellow owners.
If you need additional help or have more questions or details to share, please join the site so you can reply in this thread. See this link for instructions on how to join Android Central.
Mod Note: Thread moved for better visibility.

Hopefully, someone there can help me sort this out.
Bob

replies.text:
Hello Bob! Thanks for registering and welcome to the forums! Let me ask a couple of question to be sure I completely understand your problem. Do you get a red mic icon when voice typing? As far as I know editing texts by voice commands is very limited to just a couple of Google programs and under some conditions.
Also, in your first post it wasn't clear which Moto model you have. It is the G5 plus, right? If so, we could move your thread to the specific forum.

title: Moto G5 Plus - Thinking of buying

thread.text:
I recently bricked my iPhone 6s, and I've been looking at a few mid-range Android phones as a replacement, but the Noto G5 + is the one I find the most intriguing (Honor 8 is the other big frontrunner). My biggest concerns with buying a phone are overall reliability, battery life (which was terrible on the iPhone 6s, and audio quality (via headphones). Aside from the basics, I listen to a ton of music on my phone non-stop, read emails, watch YouTube... the only game I really play is Pokemon Go. Can anyone share their experiences with their Moto G 5 Pluses so far? This would be my first time jumping off the Apple train, and anytime I go to Reddit or other Android forums, they are riddled with bizarre issues with their Android phones.
(Note: I'm not a big fan of 5.5-and-above- phones, and the Z Play is just too unwieldy for me).

replies.text: This phone is amazing, battery life is all day, for me I have WiFi on and stream a solid 8 hours of podcasts at work and YouTube on my break and battery is at 70% when I leave work and also play Pokemon go and is at 30% at 11pm, I unplug it at 3:30am, solid phone all around

thread.text: The g5 plus is a solid phone! I would consider the phone reliable it's been a great since I've owned it. In fact I've not touched my iPhone 7+ for weeks because of using this phone.

I have been extremely happy with my G5+. Amazing battery life as others have said - I almost never charge in the middle of the day. Also very smooth scrolling without stuttering or lag despite having a mid-range processor. And all this for an amazing price.
That being said...
...audio is one place I have not been as happy as I thought. It uses the earpiece as a loudspeaker, which is nice because it's front firing instead of on the back or bottom. Yet... it is not as clear or loud as I thought it would be when on speakerphone or watching videos. It is not bad - just that I thought it would be markedly improved vs other phones. Sound output through headphones and BT have been fine though, so maybe this will be fine for you.
The other thing is the size. Although screen is 5.2" if you check out the physical dimensions of the phone it is as large as many 5.5" phones despite having a smaller screen. Almost identical in physical dimensions vs my prior LG G4 despite a reduction of screen from 5.5 -> 5.2. And larger than my old G2 despite both having a 5.2" screen. I guess that's what you give up at this price point 
I am still happy with my G5+, but before getting one, you may want to review vs the Axon 7 / 7 Mini (both I think have front stereo speakers and do some size comparisons on phonearena etc before purchasing.
I'd put the G5 Plus right in between an iPhone 6 and 6+ on size. It's kind of klunky for Android phones, but probably typical for iPhones, with respect to screen/phone size ratios.

I got a Motorola G5 Plus phone on Monday, July 3rd, after my Nexus 5 phone gave up on me...the Motorola phone is very nice: stock Android 7.0 (not the latest updates though), very smooth movement from screen to screen, long lasting battery, feels premium. The screen is 5.2" but the phone itself is bit (maybe 5.5" with the bezels on top and bottom).
Did you make a decision on the phone?

title: How are photos organized in Android 7.0 Nougat on Moto G5 plus?

thread.text:
I just bought a Moto G5+. I transferred a bunch of data (texts, contacts, photos, etc.) from my old phone to my new phone using the T-Mobile Content Transfer app (which might have complicated things). For now, I am just trying to understand what happened to my photos, how they are organized, and where they are stored on my phone. I have a 128GB SD card installed and I have modified my camera settings to store my photos on the memory (SD) card.
When I use the Google Photos app on my phone, I see things I do not expect and cannot figure out. For example, the DCIM/Camera folder on my SD card contains about 285 images. But when I open Google Photos, I only see 6 photos under "Camera".
When I snoop around in the phone's storage, I start at the phone's storage settings (see below).
Then I tap Internal Shared Storage (see below)
Then I tap Images (see below)
The things that confuse me:
1. There are multiple folders with the same name (e.g., there are two Camera folders and not shown in the screen shot are two more GroupMe folders for a total of 3).
2. None of these folders contain only those six photos that Google Photos is showing me under "Camera".
3. The Camera folders each contain 200+ images but Google Photos is not showing them to me. 
Can someone explain the design, rationale, approach that makes sense out of what looks like a confusing structure? Again, note that the T-Mobile Content Transfer app may have complicated things.
Thanks much.
I just realized that I posted this question for a Moto G5 in the Samsung Galaxy S5 Forum. I was not paying attention. My apologies.

replies.text:
I have asked that it be moved for you.
You are seeing double folders because you set the SD card as default for the camera, so that creates a 'set' of standard folders that were also created on your phone when you transferred over the photos. Google Photos is an organizer, it takes your photos and "organizes" them for you whether you want it to or not. If you go hunting past it's opening screen you should fine the rest. There are also different views. I much prefer the default Gallery as it shows folders and pics the way I want instead of changing them all around to 'help me'.
Thread moved to the G5 & G5+ fórum.

title: Links within apps not working

I don't think that's necessary. Maybe you could try clearing data for Chrome and then reboot the phone, if you don't mind losing any personal info included in the app that is not synced with your account.
Does this happen while on WiFi, mobile or both? Also, if you have the Developer Options enabled go there and make sure that the option to change the Webview service is disabled.

I do have developer options enabled - checked just now and WebView implementation is set to Chrome Stable and Multiprocess WebView is turned off. Hopefully that matches what you recommended. As I said in my original post, it seems to happen in both WiFi and LTE.
I don't have any personal info in Chrome that I would lose so I will try clearing data for it and seeing what happens. Since this is not really repeatable, I will have to just go day by day and see if the problem goes away

VZ features: 
Share Name ID : Compatible
HD Voice - Compatible (Disable this feature if you want to call 911)
NFL Mobile - NOT Compatible
VZ Message+ - Compatible on primary device (No Sync across devices)
INDYCAR Mobile - NOT Compatible
go90 - NOT Compatible
Stream Pass NBA - NOT Compatible
VZ Support and Protection - NOT Compatible
VZ Family Base - Compatible
Visual Voice Mail - Compatible
VZ Cloud - NOT Compatible
VZ Navigator - Compatible
Roadside Assistance - Compatible
Family Locator - Compatible
Ringback Tones - Compatible
Push To Talk Plus - Compatible
VZ Caller Name ID - NOT Compatible
I have also noticed that I do not have 4G LTE (or any LTE) signal while WiFi is enabled. I am still researching that issue. 
I hope that VZ and Lenovo/Moto figure this out in the near future, but until that happens, other Verizon Wireless customers should be aware that not all of the network features you may have beeen using in the past will be available with the G5 Plus.

title: AC Jacklyn Dallas: Moto G5 Plus vs. Honor 6X
Is this battery useage profile typical?

thread.text:
Wondering if this is typical? Have only had this phone for a few weeks. I usually don't pay particular attention to how power is being consumed, but I could have sworn that with other phones the screen was always the #1 power consumer. This says that "google app" and "google services" together are using nearly 3 times as much power as the screen. 
Is this normal? Should I be doing something to "fix" this?

Well, if you never turn on the screen, the apps are still active in the background so they will use more power. You can limit them in settings by stopping background data and you may have data saver function which will limit background stuff. Auto synch is another one... 
So it's largely reliant on use...
What kind of screen-on time (SOT) do you get if you tap on the screen button in the screen above? That might give a clue whether you are using more screen time than you thought

That was a heavy screen use day for me. I think it was well over an hour. That's why I was surprised to see that the screen was only accounted 10% of battery use over that 12 hour period. My phone was down to about 30% charge. "Google App" and "Google Services" accounted for 20%(29% of 70%) of my battery 
use by themselves over that 12 hours. I just wasn't sure if that was typical, or quite an abnormality. 
I don't even know what those Google items actually do. They surely used more juice than my screen, android OS, and cell standby combined though. That seems suspect to me.

I had a problem similar to that when Google Contacts got stuck in some sort of sync loop. It had trouble syncing and wouldn't stop trying and sucked up the battery. You might want to take a look at your sync status. Maybe try wiping the cache partition as well.

title: iPhone 6 compared to the G5 Plus ?

thread.text: Anyone go from an iPhone 6 to the Moto G5 Plus? If so, what are your thoughts? I'm especially interested in a camera performance comparison. Thanks!

I've never used neither so this comment is solely based on reviews and my experience with several Motorola devices.
First off the G5 Plus is a budget phone (some will also call it mid-range so let's just say it's not a flagship). So you may lose a bit on general performance (especially with the 2GB version). I'm not sure about the iPhone 6's camera performance in low light but Motorola cameras has never been very good in low light. So if your iPhone 6 is good in that respect, you'll lose a bit there too. Motorola cameras tends to also lose a bit of the color in pictures: people look paler in certain settings. They're not generally known for their cameras.
Otherwise, although I don't own a Moto G5 Plus, Motorola/Lenovo generally have great performing phones on low/mid-range budget phones. So that shouldn't be a problem as such.
Now if you're able to pay a bit more and don't absolutely need to get a Motorola device, you could also go with a OnePlus 3T or a Samsung S7 which are high end phones but that don't cost all that much. Both devices have pretty good cameras.
I personally have an S7 right now which has a great camera but am looking forward to the Moto Z2 Play that should come out in the coming months (I'm a stock Android fan and Motorola are the only devices I can affort :P). So when that comes out I'll sell my S7 to buy out my contract and get that new Motorola device (camera performance have never been really important to me).
Hope this helped!

I have the 4GB/64GB version of the G5 Plus and I agree with what dialonde said. The G5 is a budget/mid-range device and really can't be expected to match a high end phone in every regard. The phone is fast and smooth in everyday use. The display is ok, as is the camera. Different camera apps may help a bit with picture quality but no app can make up for anything the sensor lacks.
If you're coming from an iPhone you may not be happy with a budget Android phone. As mentioned you might want to spend a bit more especially if camera performance is important to you.
I myself was looking for a decent device with tons of storage plus expandable storage that wouldn't break the bank. I just can't bring myself to spend $700 to $1000 on a phone. For my purposes the camera is fine. 
Also if security patches are important don't look at Motorola. Thier record of providing patches is miserable, to say the least. I knew that going in and have a Nexus 5X which does get patched as a spare.

Thanks guys. Truth is I don't need the best camera on the market but I DO want a camera that is at least as good as what I've got on the iPhone 6. I don't need better, but I don't want worse. Know what I mean?

Then you may want to look at some mid-ranges or cheaper high end like I suggested. The OnePlus 3T and S7 are cheaper than the current flagships but offer both great performance and camera. If your budget allows it of course!

title: Quick Moto G5 Plus impressions

thread.text:
Quick user review. 
I purchased the Moto G5 (64GB/4GB) from Best Buy on launch day and so far I'm very impressed. My comparison is against the 2015 Moto X pure Edition. So far I am most impressed by the G5 battery life. Under heavy use I'm getting well over one day of usage. The feeling that I need to carry a charger around with me is gone with this phone. Streaming music and YouTube videos along with Facebook messenger and multiple phone calls throughout the day I haven't had one hiccup yet. 
I like the One Touch navigation feature and I have been using it since I unboxed the device. There is a learning curve to it but once you get the hang of it it's a Nifty trick and it adds to the uniqueness. Nougat runs well and split screen works very well. 
The biggest negatives in my opinion are the single firing speaker and the absence of the "wave to wake" feature my Moto X has. Dropping from a 5.7 inch higher end display to this G5's 5.2 took a little time to adjust too but ultimately found it not to be an issue. The camera on the G5 is hit and miss. I've taken some impressive photos in the daylight but once the sun sets it's a whole other story. I think the Moto X could edge the G5 out but only slightly. 
Some things I haven't tested are HD video recording, the headphone input, or streaming Bluetooth audio to a car. The lack of NFC doesn't bother me. 
Overall I'd recommend the phone as a replacement for the Moto X. I'm keeping the Moto X as a backup for now.
Thank you for your thoughts and insight.
I'm curious about battery life? Any thoughts would be appreciated.

It's been good for me with constant use and it has turbo charging shocked how fast it will fully charge ,does get a bit warm charging nothing to be concerned about , right now I don't fell the need for a car charger , however my iPhone 7+ still wins in the battery department
Mod note: Fixed the thread title from G4 to G5.
Thanks for your review. I'm considering a G5 Plus to replace my 5X. It seems like a great phone for the money.
Find it interesting it doesn't have the wave to wake up feature, since the G5 has a proximity sensor.

replies.text: Second gen Moto X and up use IR.
When you wave the flashlight comes on ,when you shake the camera comes on.

Not necessarily the twist action launches camera, and the chop action launched flashlight. Hard to believe you missed the fact that he is referring to which is waving your hand over the screen as one of the moto actions.
Oops your right note taken 😁

thread.text: Well the battery on mine went bad over night after 12 days wouldn't hold a charge, so I took it back, my only complaint about the phone is the display color was a bit on the cool blue side and not adjustable but overall great phone, however because of the battery I decided to switch to the Huawei mate 9

I'm pleasantly surprised at the g5 plus. I picked one up as a spare phone while waiting for my s8. It has been great so far. Battery life is excellent as good as the z play I had. Built excellent. Great little device. Especially for the price.

title: G5 Plus vs G3

thread.text:
There are lots of interesting reviews out there. Most of them mention how certain aspects compare to G4 Plus. Which makes perfect sense, but it's utterly useless to me. 
Can someone comment from experience on how Moto G5 Plus compares to Moto G3 in terms of battery life, audio quality on speaker / wired headphones / bluetooth, and camera performance?
I like the idea of SD625 but actually my G3 works fine and I usually have 30% battery left at the end of the day, though it varies of course. (Also I occasionally miss the compass.)

Depends on what you do with your phone. If you only listen to music, browse the web, etc then no reason to upgrade. 
Camera is definitely improved from G3 to G5 but is the upgrade significant enough to upgrade? Depends on how important camera quality is to you, it may be worth upgrading if you take a lot of pictures. 
Battery life is only slightly better, not worthy of upgrade. 
If you like to play intensive 3D games on your phone, then SD625 chipset is massive improvement over SD410 in G3.
I'm in the same boat as you, thinking of upgrading from a G3 to G5 Plus. I was able to find this comparison:Motorola Moto G (3rd gen) vs. Motorola Moto G5 Plus - GSMArena.com

That only addressees the technical specifications differences.
Personally, they had such a winner with the G3 I don't know why they didn't just improve the internals and keep everything else the same. E.g.: One complaint I've seen of the G5 is the fake metal back and fake chrome trim. The former making it harder to hold and the latter scratching easily.
Seriously, Lenovorola: This is not a flagship device. No need to try to make it more than it is. Never mind that fake chrome always looks like just what it is: Fake chrome.
The lightly-textured back on my G3 is one of its most attractive features, in my view. If I buy one of these it'll be getting a thin case ordered with it. First time I'll ever have put a Moto G in a case.
The only reason I'm even considering this device is the B12 and WiFi calling support. Otherwise I'd just keep my G3.

title: Moto G5 Plus - will the US sim free version work with a UK sim card?

thread.text:
I'm getting a new phone and I'm pretty set on the Motorola G5 Plus. I live in the UK but I will be traveling to the US soon and I'm considering buying a new phone while I'm there ($230 vs £250 here which is about a £50 difference even with MA sales tax).
Anyway - I am wondering if the G5 Plus from the US would work without any issues in the UK and the rest of Europe with a UK sim card. I googled around a bit and found some info on GSM bands but I hope that someone knowledgeable will be able to give me a definite answer.
This is what I found on Motorola's official website regarding this phone's bands:
Moto G Plus - XT1687 CDMA (850, 850+,1900 MHz) GSM/GPRS/EDGE (850, 900, 1800, 1900 MHz) UMTS/HSPA+ (850, 900, 1700, 1900, 2100 MHz) 4G LTE (B1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 12, 13, 17, 25, 26, 38, 41, 66)
I have also found bands supported by British carriers and they seem compatible to me but I would like to be sure first (it's also quite important that it works in the rest of Western Europe as I travel from time to time).
Thank you in advance!
Check also whether warranties are regional.

You'll need to find out what specific bands the carrier(s) you intend to use the phone on and compare to your list here. If they are all supported you should be fine. If you are missing some, you might have problems getting LTE in some areas, but 3G HSPA shouldn't be a problem.
Definitely double check the bands (especially LTE), but most phones will work around the world up to 3G and 4G (HSPA+) speeds. As for MA....if you can sneak up into NH, there's no sales tax.
